metadata.titleEn: Lake sediment-surface pollen dataset for alpine meadow in eastern Tibetan Plateau
metadata.description:
Relationship between modern pollen and climate, and its representative to vegetation are the important references in explaining and reconstructing past climate and vegetation qualitatively or quantitatively. To extrct past climate and vegetation signals from fossil pollen spectrum of a lacustrine sediment, a corresponding modern pollen dataset collected from lake-sediment surface is necessary. At present, there are a few modern pollen datasets extracted from lake sediment-surface established on the Tibetan Plateau, however, the geographic gaps (e.g. the central and east Tibetan Plateau) of available sampled lakes influence the correct understanding.
To ensure the even distribution of the representative lakes, we collected lake sediment-surface samples (n=117) covering the alpine meadow evenly on the east and central Tibetan Plateau, in July and August 2018. For pollen extraction, approximately 10 g (wet original sediment) per sample were sub-sampled. Pollen sample was processed by the standard acid-alkali-acid procedures followed by 7-μm-mesh sieving. More than 500 terrestrial pollen grains were counted for each sample.
Pollen assemblages of the dataset from alpine meadow are dominated by Cyperaceae (mean is 68.4%, maximum is 95.9%), with other herbaceous pollen taxa as commen taxa including Poaceae (mean is 10.3%, maximum is 87.7%), Ranunculaceae (mean is 4.8%, maximum is 33.6%), Artemisia (mean is 3.7%, maximum is 24.5%), Asteraceae (mean is 2.1%, maximum is 33.6%), etc. Salix (mean is 0.4%, maximum is 5.3%) is the major shrub taxon in these pollen assemblages, while arboreal taxa occur with low percentages generally (mean of total arboreal percentages is 0.9% (maximum is 5.8%), including mainly Pinus (mean is 0.3%, maximum is 1.8%), Betula (mean is 0.1%, maximum is 0.9%) and Alnus (mean is 0.1%, maximum is 0.7%). These pollen assemblages represent the plant components well in the alpine meadow communities, although they are influenced slightly by long-distance pollen grain transported by wind or river (such as these arboreal pollen taxa).
Together with pollen counts and percentages, we also provided the modern climatic data for the sampled lakes. The China Meteorological Forcing Dataset (CMFD; gridded near-surface meteorological dataset) with a temporal resolution of three hours and a spatial resolution of 0.1° was employed, and the climatic data of the nearest pixel of one sampled lake was defined to represent climatic conditions of the lake. Finally, the mean annual precipitation (Pann), mean annual temperature (Tann) and mean temperature of the coldest month (Mtco) and warmest month (Mtwa) are calculated for each sampled lake.

background: The relationship between modern pollen and climate, and its representation of vegetation, is the basis for explaining and reconstructing past climate and vegetation qualitatively or quantitatively. Although there are some modern pollen datasets for the Tibetan Plateau established to investigate the relationships between pollen and climate or vegetation, there are geographical gaps (e.g., the central and eastern Tibetan Plateau) in the sampled lakes which may bias interpretations. The available modern pollen datasets reveal that pollen assemblages on the Tibetan Plateau are generally simple with Cyperaceae, Artemisia, Poaceae, and Chenopodiaceae as the dominant taxa and with arboreal pollen taxa becoming more influential in the marginal areas. It is essential to identify the climatic indicators of the modern pollen taxa (particular for the four dominant taxa) on the Tibetan Plateau because the climatic indicators derived from modern pollen datasets from the surrounding lowland cannot be directly employed on the Tibetan Plateau.
research objective: With our current modern pollen dataset extracted from lake surface sediments, we aim to (1) fill a geographical gap and thus establish a comprehensive modern pollen dataset covering the entire Tibetan Plateau; (2) determine the climatic indicators for common pollen taxa from the alpine meadow ecosystem; and (3) evaluate the predictive power of the modern dataset to reconstruct past climate and assess the reliability of the random forest (RF) algorithm in calibrating the pollen–climate relationship.
challenges: Although the selected lakes generally have an even distribution, there is still a gap in the south-west part of the study area because of a lack of lake and road access.
methods: To ensure the even distribution of the representative lakes, we travelled not only along the hardened roads but also the dirt roads to collect samples from the alpine meadow on the eastern and central Tibetan Plateau in July and August 2018. The lake surface sediment samples were collected from the central part of each lake, with the top 2 cm of lake sediment forming the sample. For pollen extraction, approximately 10 g (wet untreated sediment) per sample was subsampled. Pollen samples were processed using standard acid–alkali–acid procedures (including 10 % HCl, 10 % KOH, 40 % HF, and a 9:1 mixture of acetic anhydride and sulfuric acid successively), followed by 7 µm mesh sieving. A tablet with Lycopodium spores (27,560 grains per tablet) was added to each sample prior to pollen extraction as tracers. Pollen grains were identified with the aid of modern pollen reference slides collected from the eastern and central Tibetan Plateau (including 401 common species of alpine meadow) and published atlases for pollen and spores. More than 500 terrestrial pollen grains were counted for each sample, and more than 200 Lycopodium spores were counted for most of the samples.
dataset: Lake surface sediment samples (n =117) were collected from the alpine meadow region on the Tibetan Plateau between elevations of 3720 and 5170 m a.s.l. The region covered by these modern pollen samples has a Pann gradient from 226 to 689 mm and cold thermal conditions with low Tann (−7.3 to 2.3 °C) and Mt co (−19.2 to −7.4 °C). Pollen datasets including both pollen counts and percentages for each sample, together with their site location and climatic data, are available at the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center (TPDC; Cao et al., 2021; https://doi.org/10.11888/Paleoenv.tpdc.271191).
findings: Numerical analyses reveal that Pann is the most important climatic determinant for pollen distribution in the dataset. Our dataset behaves reliably and has good predictive power for past moisture reconstruction, and the random forest algorithm is a potentially reliable approach in pollen-based past environment reconstruction.

Verification.Question: Are lake surface sediment samples used as a data collection method for pollen extraction in the Tibetan Plateau alpine meadow region?
Is there a challenge in collecting samples from the south-west part of the Tibetan Plateau due to a lack of lake and road access?

Disjunctive.Question: Which factor is considered the most significant climatic determinant for pollen distribution in datasets from the Tibetan Plateau: annual precipitation (Pann), mean annual temperature (Tann), or elevation?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the challenges faced in collecting lake surface sediment samples in the alpine meadow region of the Tibetan Plateau?
Concept Completion.Answer: uneven geographical distribution and accessibility issues

Concept Completion.Question: Where were the lake surface sediment samples collected to ensure an even distribution in the alpine meadow region?
What data collection method is used to ensure the accuracy of pollen extraction from lake surface sediments?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how samples from lake sediments are collected to ensure even distribution across a geographical area?
Example.Answer: To ensure even distribution, samples from lake sediments were collected by traveling along both hardened and dirt roads. Sediment samples were taken from the central part of each lake, with the top 2 cm of sediment forming the sample. This approach was used in the eastern and central Tibetan Plateau during July and August 2018.

Example.Question: What is an example of a method used to extract and process pollen from lake sediment samples?
Example.Answer: Pollen extraction from lake sediment samples involves subsampling approximately 10 g of wet untreated sediment. The samples undergo standard acid–alkali–acid procedures, including treatments with 10% HCl, 10% KOH, 40% HF, and a 9:1 mixture of acetic anhydride and sulfuric acid, followed by sieving with a 7 µm mesh.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the properties of pollen assemblages in lake surface sediments from the Tibetan Plateau's alpine meadow region?
Feature Specification.Answer: dominance of Cyperaceae pollen, common herbaceous pollen types such as Poaceae, Ranunculaceae, Artemisia, Asteraceae, presence of shrub and tree pollen in lower amounts, main shrub and tree pollen types include Salix, Pinus, Betula, Alnus

Feature Specification.Question: What are the key attributes of the data collection methods used for assembling pollen datasets in high-altitude regions such as the Tibetan Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: lake surface sediment samples, central part of each lake, standard acid–alkali–acid procedures, 7 µm mesh, Lycopodium spores as tracers, more than 500 terrestrial pollen grains counted per sample, elevations between 3720 and 5170 m, Pann gradient from 226 to 689 mm, cold thermal conditions

Quantification.Question: How many lake surface sediment samples were collected for the modern pollen dataset in the alpine meadow region on the Tibetan Plateau?
What is the range of elevations from which the lake surface sediment samples were collected in the alpine meadow region on the Tibetan Plateau?

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'pollen extraction' in the context of retrieving data from lake surface sediments?
Definition.Answer: Pollen extraction refers to the process of isolating pollen grains from lake surface sediments using standard acid–alkali–acid procedures, which include treatments with hydrochloric acid (HCl), potassium hydroxide (KOH), hydrofluoric acid (HF), and a mixture of acetic anhydride and sulfuric acid. The process also involves sieving through a 7 µm mesh to ensure that the pollen is separated from other sediment particles.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection methods between modern pollen datasets from the lowland areas and those collected from the alpine meadow region on the Tibetan Plateau?
Comparison.Answer: Modern pollen datasets from the alpine meadow region on the Tibetan Plateau are collected from lake surface sediments at high elevations (3720 to 5170 m a.s.l.) using a detailed acid–alkali–acid procedure for pollen extraction. In contrast, lowland datasets may not require such rigorous methods due to different environmental conditions. Additionally, climatic indicators from lowland areas are not directly applicable to the Tibetan Plateau, necessitating specific calibration for alpine conditions.

Comparison.Question: How does the predictive power of pollen datasets for reconstructing past climates on the Tibetan Plateau compare when using the random forest algorithm versus other potential modeling approaches?
Comparison.Answer: The pollen dataset from the Tibetan Plateau shows reliable predictive power for past moisture reconstruction using the random forest algorithm. This approach is potentially more reliable compared to other modeling techniques, as numerical analyses indicate that precipitation (Pann) is a significant climate determinant for pollen distribution, which the random forest algorithm can effectively capture.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges arise in evenly distributing sampling sites across high-altitude regions, and how might these be overcome in the context of pollen data collection?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include geographical barriers such as lack of accessible roads and the absence of lakes in certain regions, which can lead to sampling gaps. Overcoming these challenges requires strategic planning, including travelling along both hardened and dirt roads, and possibly using alternative transportation methods to reach remote areas, ensuring a more representative distribution of sampling sites.

Interpretation.Question: How might the integration of climatic data with pollen datasets enhance the reconstruction of past climates in high-altitude ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating climatic data such as annual precipitation and temperature metrics with pollen datasets allows for a more robust calibration of pollen-climate relationships. This integration enhances the ability to reconstruct past climate conditions by establishing stronger predictive models, such as using the random forest algorithm, to interpret how current pollen assemblages reflect historical climatic scenarios.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the incomplete representation of vegetation types and climate gradients in existing pollen datasets from the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The incomplete representation of vegetation types and climate gradients in existing pollen datasets from the Tibetan Plateau is due to geographical gaps in sample collection, especially in the central and eastern regions. These gaps can lead to biased interpretations of pollen assemblages, as they do not adequately cover the diverse vegetation and climate variability across the plateau.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What could be the reasons for the south-west part of the Tibetan Plateau study area having gaps in lake surface sediment sample coverage?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The south-west part of the Tibetan Plateau study area has gaps in lake surface sediment sample coverage due to the lack of accessible lakes and roads. This logistical challenge makes it difficult for researchers to collect samples evenly across the region, resulting in an incomplete dataset for that area.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of utilizing standard acid–alkali–acid procedures for pollen extraction in terms of data quality and completeness in pollen datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing standard acid–alkali–acid procedures ensures that pollen grains are effectively separated and preserved, resulting in high-quality and complete pollen datasets. This method allows for the accurate identification and quantification of pollen types, which is crucial for constructing reliable pollen-climate calibration sets and reconstructing past environments.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives behind creating a comprehensive pollen data collection method in the alpine meadow region of the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives are to fill geographical gaps in existing pollen datasets, determine climatic indicators for common pollen taxa in the alpine meadow ecosystem, and evaluate the predictive power of the dataset for reconstructing past climates, particularly using the random forest algorithm for calibrating pollen–climate relationships.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to identify climatic indicators for pollen taxa specifically within the Tibetan Plateau's alpine meadow ecosystem?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Identifying climatic indicators for pollen taxa within the Tibetan Plateau's alpine meadow ecosystem is important because climatic indicators derived from surrounding lowland areas cannot be directly employed in this region. This is due to the unique environmental and climatic conditions of the Tibetan Plateau, which differ significantly from those of lower altitudes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended benefits of collecting lake surface sediment samples from a wide elevation range on the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended benefits of collecting lake surface sediment samples from a wide elevation range are to ensure even distribution of samples across the region, accurately represent the diverse climatic conditions, and capture a comprehensive picture of the pollen assemblages and their relationship to climate gradients, which is essential for reliable past climate reconstruction.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in ensuring the even distribution of representative lake samples in the alpine meadow region of the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To ensure the even distribution of representative lakes, researchers traveled along both hardened roads and dirt roads to collect samples from the alpine meadow on the eastern and central Tibetan Plateau. The lake surface sediment samples were collected from the central part of each lake, with the top 2 cm of lake sediment forming the sample.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is pollen extraction from lake surface sediments conducted, and what are the key steps involved in the process?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Pollen extraction involves subsampling approximately 10 g of wet untreated sediment per sample. The samples undergo standard acid–alkali–acid procedures including treatment with 10% HCl, 10% KOH, 40% HF, and a 9:1 mixture of acetic anhydride and sulfuric acid, followed by sieving through a 7 µm mesh. A tablet with Lycopodium spores is added to each sample as a tracer prior to pollen extraction, and pollen grains are identified using modern pollen reference slides and published atlases.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What challenges are faced in the geographical sampling of lakes for pollen data collection, and how are these challenges addressed?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: One of the challenges is the lack of lake and road access in certain areas, such as the south-west part of the study area. Despite this, researchers ensured an even distribution of the representative lakes by traveling not only along hardened roads but also dirt roads to access more remote locations.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable the collection of pollen samples from lake sediments in remote and high-altitude regions such as the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: To ensure the even distribution of representative lakes, samples were collected by traveling along both hardened and dirt roads in the eastern and central Tibetan Plateau. Lake surface sediment samples were collected from the central part of each lake, with the top 2 cm of sediment forming the sample. This approach enabled the collection of samples even in remote and high-altitude regions.

Enablement.Question: How does the use of modern pollen reference slides enhance the identification and analysis of pollen grains in sediment samples?
Enablement.Answer: The identification of pollen grains was enhanced by the use of modern pollen reference slides collected from the eastern and central Tibetan Plateau, which included 401 common species of alpine meadow. This, along with published atlases for pollen and spores, aided in accurately identifying more than 500 terrestrial pollen grains per sample.

Enablement.Question: What are the conditions necessary for establishing a comprehensive modern pollen dataset that represents diverse vegetation types and climate gradients on the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The establishment of a comprehensive modern pollen dataset requires filling geographical gaps by collecting samples from a wide range of elevations (3720 to 5170 m a.s.l.) and climatic conditions (Pann gradient from 226 to 689 mm, Tann from −7.3 to 2.3 °C). It also necessitates an even distribution of sampling sites and adequate road access to ensure the representation of diverse vegetation types and climate gradients.

Expectation.Question: What expectations might researchers have when using modern pollen datasets to reconstruct past climates, and what factors could impact the accuracy of these reconstructions?
Expectation.Answer: Researchers might expect that modern pollen datasets can reliably predict past climates by serving as climatic indicators. However, the accuracy of these reconstructions may be impacted by the influence of far-travelled arboreal pollen and the need for climatic indicators specific to the Tibetan Plateau, as indicators from surrounding lowlands cannot be directly applied.

Expectation.Question: Why might researchers expect certain taxa to be dominant in the pollen datasets from alpine meadows, and how does this affect the interpretation of past vegetation and climate?
Expectation.Answer: Researchers might expect taxa like Cyperaceae, Poaceae, and Artemisia to be dominant due to their prevalence in the alpine meadow ecosystems. This dominance can affect interpretations by providing clear signals of the local vegetation and climate, which are crucial for reconstructing past environments accurately.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of the pollen extraction methods used in collecting surface sediment samples from lakes in alpine meadow regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The pollen extraction methods, which involve standard acid–alkali–acid procedures and 7 µm mesh sieving, are effective in isolating pollen grains from lake surface sediments. The addition of Lycopodium spores as tracers further enhances the accuracy of pollen quantification. These methods are well-suited for the alpine meadow regions as they adequately preserve pollen integrity, allowing for reliable identification and counting of over 500 terrestrial pollen grains per sample.

Judgmental.Question: What is your perspective on the challenges faced in ensuring the even distribution of representative lake samples in high-altitude regions?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges primarily stem from geographical constraints, such as the lack of lakes and road access, particularly in the south-west part of the study area. Despite these limitations, efforts to travel along both hardened and dirt roads to collect samples demonstrate a commitment to achieving a more representative spatial distribution. These logistical hurdles are significant but not insurmountable, and addressing them is crucial for comprehensive dataset coverage.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how might the lack of modern pollen data in certain regions affect the reliability of climate and vegetation reconstructions?
Judgmental.Answer: The absence of modern pollen data in specific regions, like the central and eastern Tibetan Plateau, creates gaps that can bias climate and vegetation reconstructions. Without comprehensive data coverage, interpretations may lack accuracy and precision, particularly in representing the diverse vegetation types and climate gradients. This limitation underscores the importance of expanding data collection efforts to include underrepresented areas, enhancing the reliability of ecological and climatic inferences.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how data collection methods ensure an even distribution of representative samples in geographically challenging areas like the Tibetan Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: To ensure an even distribution of representative samples, the researchers traveled along both hardened and dirt roads to collect samples from the alpine meadow regions on the eastern and central Tibetan Plateau. They collected lake surface sediment samples from the central part of each lake and used standard procedures for pollen extraction.

Assertion.Question: I'm not clear on what challenges might arise when trying to establish a comprehensive modern pollen dataset across a diverse and remote area like the Tibetan Plateau.
Assertion.Answer: One of the challenges is the geographical gap in the south-west part of the study area due to a lack of lakes and road access, which can impede the establishment of a comprehensive dataset.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the data collection methods used to ensure an even distribution of lake surface sediment samples in the alpine meadow region.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection involved traveling along both hardened and dirt roads to collect samples from the alpine meadow on the eastern and central Tibetan Plateau in July and August 2018. Lake surface sediment samples were collected from the central part of each lake, with the top 2 cm of lake sediment forming the sample. Approximately 10 g of wet untreated sediment per sample was subsampled for pollen extraction.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in obtaining a comprehensive pollen dataset for the Tibetan Plateau and propose potential strategies to address these gaps.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges include geographical gaps in the sampled lakes, particularly in the south-west part of the study area due to a lack of lake and road access. To address these gaps, strategies could involve the use of alternative transportation methods, such as drones or helicopters, for remote sampling, and collaboration with local communities to gain access to less accessible areas.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the significance of climatic indicators derived from modern pollen datasets in reconstructing past climate conditions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Climatic indicators from modern pollen datasets are essential for reconstructing past climate conditions, as they help determine the relationship between pollen taxa and climate variables. The dataset indicates that Pann (annual precipitation) is a crucial climatic determinant for pollen distribution, and the predictive power of the dataset for past moisture reconstruction is reliable. This underlines the importance of accurately identifying climatic indicators to enhance the reliability of past climate reconstructions.
